awd_titl_txt: Advancing Understanding of the Tornado Vortex through Numerical Simulations of Increasing Complexity and Evaluation of Observing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Detailed understanding of the structure and variability of winds in the core of tornadoes remains incomplete.  While recent advances in observational technology (particularly Doppler radars) have revealed the inner-core structure of the primary tangential circulation, large uncertainties remain regarding the secondary (radial and vertical) circulations, and there remains a paucity of information concerning flow near the surface (below 50 meters) where most of the inflow to tornadoes resides.  Previous simulations of tornado-producing supercells portray believable, detailed structures of the tornado near the surface, but their inherent complexity has inhibited understanding of the most basic dynamics of tornadoes.  Simpler tornado-chamber-type simulations facilitate understanding, but almost all previous simulations have used prescribed inflow and outflow boundary conditions that preclude interactions between the tornado and the larger environment that creates it.  The research in this project will bridge the gaps between theory (primarily from highly idealized, low-Reynolds-number, axisymmetric simulations), aforementioned storm-scale simulations that are far more complex, and observations (which always have limited spatial and temporal coverage).  A widely-used numerical model (CM1) will be used to perform simulations of tornado-like vortices of increasing complexity, ranging from axisymmetric simulations with no-slip lower boundary conditions and constant eddy viscosity to three-dimensional large eddy simulation (LES) with realistic surface roughness.  In addition, select high resolution direct numerical simulations (DNS) will be used to assess the accuracy of subgrid turbulence parameterizations, especially near the surface.  Output from these simulations will also be used to assess the extent to which current (and perhaps future) instruments and analysis procedures are capable of reconstructing three-dimensional wind fields from limited observational data.

Broader impacts of this effort will include improved assessment of the near-surface wind fields of tornadoes as a function of vortex size, intensity, and over different surface conditions, which will in-turn help to guide the collection analysis of data from past and future field campaigns.  The extent to which data obtained from recent field campaigns (such as VORTEX2) can accurately diagnose tornado wind fields will be evaluated, leading to better analyses of data from past campaigns and better designs for future campaigns.  The project will support education mentoring and career development of a post-doctoral fellow.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to increase our understanding of the wind flow and its variability (i.e., gusts and turbulence) in the cores of tornadoes. To obtain this information we used computer models to simulate the interaction of a tornado-like vortex with the ground. To improve on previous simulations of this type, we developed a way to introduce turbulence into the wind flow as it approached the center of the tornado, making the wind fields there more realistic.

These simulations revealed wind gusts with intensities even beyond what we had expected, with 3-second gusts approacing 150 m/s (about 300 mph), and perhaps more remarkably, updrafts near the surface exceeding 50 m/s (about 100 mph). This can explain how large debris becomes lifted off the surface in real tornadoes. We also used these simulations to understand the relationships between tornado size, peak wind speeds, and the areas of damaging winds. While small tornadoes can have the most extreme winds (up to 300 mph), the area covered by these winds is very small (perhaps only 100 meters across). Large tornadoes do not produce such extreme wind speeds, but can producing damaging winds over paths as large as 1 kilometer across.

A second goal of this project was to determine what kinds of instrumentation would be necessary to actually observe these extreme winds. In addition to the fact that such instruments would have to survive these wind speeds, they would have to be deployed in such a way as to actually capture the peak winds wherever they might occur. Unfortunately, this turns out to be very difficult. In order to reliably capture the peak winds of a tornado, we found that surface instruments would have to be spaced at distances of less than 100 meters apart, which would be extremely difficult to achieve in practice. In addition, our work shows that estimates of torndo intensity based on surveys of damaged buildings and objects can also greatly underestimate the peak winds, again because of the very small chance for any one location to experience the strongest winds.

Finally, we applied this same type of analysis to radar measurements of tornado winds. Much like for fixed instruments, a combination of factors leads to the maximum radar-observed winds being much less than the fastest wind speeds that are actually occurring in a tornado.

An important limitation of all of this work is that the simulations could not account for 1) the presence of buildings or structures (or trees), and 2) the effects of debris generated by the tornado winds. We hope to include these prcoesses in a future project.
